header.title: The Scroll of Set, Issue Number 38
header.category: Western Esotericism, Setian Philosophy, Practical Magic

central_thesis: The Temple of Set provides a structured path for individual self-evolution (Xeper) towards higher consciousness and self-mastery, achieved through the systematic practice of White and Black Magic, rigorous self-observation, philosophical adherence to principles like Maat, and direct engagement with the entity Set as a means to transformation.

structure_content.chapter_title: From Psychology to Philosophy, or Know Thyself
structure_content.summary: This article posits that ancient psychology, fragmented into occult forms, must return to an 'all-encompassing' study of man's 'possible evolution' (Xeper) rather than stagnation. It identifies four obstacles to growth (cost, desire, comprehension, self-deception) and outlines the magician's path: developing dormant powers, acquiring new faculties, and elevating to 'higher man.' Consciousness is defined as self-observation, improved by duration and frequency, and hindered by 'four harmful functions' (lying, imagination, negative expressions, unclear talking) which must be overcome for Setamorphosis.

This piece explores the concept of 'Ancient Wisdom' as timeless knowledge guarded by a chosen few, noting its persistence in magical lore. The Temple of Set acknowledges two types of 'supernatural' entities: Set and self-created dæmons, integral to Black and White Magic. White Magic facilitates self-discovery ('Man, know thyself'), subconscious exploration, and understanding the 'hidden self.' Black Magic, involving the projection of will, is deemed effective only after White Magic provides self-knowledge. Set is presented as a unique key, an 'integrated, intelligent entity' outside the phenomenological world, providing objective knowledge beyond subjective recall.

This is an announcement detailing 'The Crystal Tablet of Set,' an introductory work for Iº initiates, covering Setian magical philosophy and practice. It provides the foundation of Setian metaphysics, principles, accouterments, and procedures of ceremonial magic, explicitly stating a lack of 'esoteric doubletalk.' A sample ceremonial format and reading list are included, emphasizing its role as a practical, foundational text exclusively for Temple members.

This article defines conscious contact with Set as the 'ultimate form of Black Magic' and the 'supreme heresy.' Set is characterized as the 'Ageless Intelligence of the Universe,' possessing vast knowledge, and serving as a *means* to Setamorphosis rather than an ideal. Such magical contact is the hallmark of III° comprehension, moving beyond mere intellectual recognition to an 'emotive assurance' of connection. Priests of Set are entrusted with acquiring knowledge beyond ordinary human reach, signifying their 'Elect' status and possession of 'Ancient Wisdom.'

This article redefines Maat beyond its conventional Egyptian association with justice and truth. For Setians, Maat is a 'way of living, of being' in 'Big-T' Truth, embodying collective principles (neteru) and representing 'the highest consciousness man can make his own.' Living in Maat, being 'true of voice' (ma'a heru), and experiencing 'Truth' as an instantaneous, compelling apprehension, are linked directly to the process of Xeper. It emphasizes self-assessment against Maat, particularly in the ritual chamber, as crucial for Setian evolution and attaining a 'True sense of Maat,' distinct from the mundane understanding lost since the Old Kingdom.

This article employs the metaphor of the 'game room' for White Magic, describing it as an initial, daily area of exercise and pleasure for Setians, where basic magical workings are learned and mastered. It emphasizes that while White Magic is valuable and effective, practitioners must not remain solely in the 'game room.' The text encourages Setians to move beyond this stage, through an 'opening door' within the self, to explore the 'terrible beauty' and 'vast blackness' of the 'realm of Black Magic.' This progression is presented as essential for Xeper, while still allowing continued use of mastered White Magic.

key_concepts.definition: The ultimate goal of individual expansion, evolution, change, and creation, leading to higher consciousness. It is the core dynamic of Setian development, contrasted with stagnation.
The process of progress towards higher consciousness and self-transformation, facilitated by the concept of the higher self and communication with Set.

Initial magical practices focused on self-discovery, subconscious exploration, and developing dormant powers. It provides power through subconscious forces and is a preparatory stage for Black Magic, necessary for understanding the 'hidden self.'

The projection of the force of the will. It requires self-knowledge gained through White Magic for effective use. Its ultimate form is conscious contact with Set, representing a deeper, more profound realm of magic.

The 'Ageless Intelligence of the Universe,' an integrated, intelligent entity existing outside the phenomenological world. Set is not an ideal to be attained but a *means* to Setamorphosis and a unique source of objective knowledge. Conscious contact with Set is considered the ultimate Black Magic.

Reinterpreted beyond its conventional Egyptian meaning of justice and truth. For Setians, Maat is a fundamental *way of living and being* in 'Big-T' Truth, originating from the 'Core Self.' It represents the highest consciousness attainable through Xeper and serves as a standard for self-judgment and conduct.
A particular kind of awareness independent of the mind's activity, cultivated through self-observation (who I am, where I am, and what I do not know). It is improved by duration and frequency.

Obstacles to self-awareness and spiritual growth: (1) Lying (known or unknown), (2) Imagination (imagining without seeing objectively), (3) Any negative expressions, and (4) Unnecessary, unclear talking. These must be actively combatted.
A persistent occult concept of hidden, timeless knowledge. Within the Temple of Set, it is posited to be accessible via both Black and White Magic, and directly through contact with the entity Set.
The deepest, most fundamental part of the individual self, distinct from the mundane personality. It is identified as the origin of 'Big-T' Truth, perceived as one becomes more attuned to it.

practical_system.description: The Setian practical system, as presented, is a structured path for individual self-evolution (Xeper) towards higher consciousness and self-mastery. It involves a progressive magical methodology beginning with rigorous self-observation to identify and overcome psychological obstacles like the 'four harmful functions.' White Magic serves as a foundational stage for self-discovery, subconscious exploration, and the development of dormant powers, which is crucial for understanding one's 'hidden self.' This mastery then enables the effective practice of Black Magic, defined as the conscious projection of the will, culminating in direct, conscious contact with the entity Set, viewed as the ultimate form of Black Magic. The Temple of Set functions as a 'school' providing the necessary techniques and communal support for this transformative growth. Adherence to Maat, reinterpreted as a living principle of 'Big-T' Truth, requires constant self-assessment against an internal standard in both daily life and ritual, driving continuous self-refinement and 'Being Maat.'

relevant_quotes.text: An acceptance of the former system (placing rest and preservation as ultimate goals) can only bring about stagnation, whereas pursuance of the latter (placing change and creating above all, or Xeper) is our concern.
This concept of higher self is an important step I feel toward our progress of Setamorphosis to be attained through higher consciousness.
Consciousness... is a particular kind of awareness independent of the mind's activity, brought about by observation of self: who I am, where I am, and what I do not in fact know.

The Temple of Set acknowledges the existence of only two forms of 'supernatural' entity: the god Set and those dæmons created by or residing within the theurgist himself. Significantly these two forms are integral ideas in the concepts of Black and White Magic respectively.
One of the prime definitions of Black Magic in the Temple of Set is conscious contact with Set. This is the ultimate form of Black Magic; the supreme 'heresy' against the universe.
Set is not so much an ideal to be attained as a means to Setamorphosis.
Nothing can be assimilated to Maat that is not of Maat's nature, true and indestructible consciousness.
Maat is in Truth the highest consciousness man can make his own.
Xeper is not exclusive of Maat; with Xeper comes Maat, for as we evolve, we become more and more able to understand our selves.
Big 'T'-Truth is something else. 'Truth' does not originate in the mundane self, but rather in the deepest part of our selves, in what I have called the Core Self.
So what exactly is this 'game room' that Priest Lewis has been talking about lately? White Magic!
The 'game room' is an area of exercise, of pleasure. It's a lot of fun, but don't stay there! Explore it, master it, and then go forward. In a Word: Xeper.

critical_analysis.relevance: This document is highly relevant to understanding the foundational philosophy and operative mechanics of the Temple of Set in its early years (1978). It articulates a distinct Western Esoteric path focused on individual self-deification (Xeper) rather than conventional spiritual attainment. The re-interpretation of 'Ancient Wisdom,' Black and White Magic, and Egyptian concepts like Maat demonstrates a unique syncretism. Set's role as a direct 'means' to Setamorphosis, rather than merely an ideal, offers a unique magical paradigm. The integration of self-observation techniques (e.g., Ouspensky's 'four harmful functions') into a magical system highlights a practical, psychologically-informed approach to occult development, distinguishing it from purely ceremonial or ritualistic traditions.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience is the membership of the Temple of Set, specifically new initiates (I°) and those progressing through the degrees (e.g., III°). The content assumes familiarity with basic Setian terminology and the organization's structure, serving as both philosophical instruction and practical guidance for internal self-development and magical work. References to 'The Crystal Tablet of Set' as an introductory text reinforce its internal focus. It would also be of significant academic interest to scholars of modern occultism, particularly those researching the history and unique doctrinal development of the Temple of Set.
